choices.explanation: Incorrect. A chair cannot be heard.
Incorrect. A board does not make sound by itself.
Correct. 'Noise' is something you can hear.
Incorrect. A flower cannot be heard.
Incorrect. A magazine is something you read.
Incorrect. A document is a written file.
Correct. Painting is an enjoyable activity, a hobby.
Incorrect. 'Fashion' refers to clothing trends.
Incorrect. The sentence suggests bravery, not anger.
Incorrect. 'Suddenly' describes timing, not attitude.
Incorrect. 'Curiously' means with curiosity.
Correct. A hero defends bravely.

questions.text: He was able to succeed because his ______ was very high.

choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Bark' refers to sound of a dog or tree covering.
Incorrect. A 'bench' is furniture.
Incorrect. 'Cardboard' is a material.
Correct. High motivation leads to success.

questions.text: The woman was not polite. She spoke very ______.

choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Sensibly' means wisely or logically.
Incorrect. Not relevant to politeness.
Incorrect. 'Sincerely' means honestly.
Correct. Someone not polite speaks rudely.

questions.text: The girl fell off her roof. What happened?

choices.explanation: Incorrect. Wrong tense; ongoing action doesn’t fit.
Incorrect. Grammar error; 'got broken' is correct form.
Correct. Describes a present result of a past action.
Incorrect. Grammar error; 'was broken' is correct form.

questions.text: What are your plans for this summer?

choices.explanation: Incorrect. Present simple doesn’t fit planned future actions.

choices.text: I have gone on a trip.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. This refers to past actions.

choices.text: I will be going on a trip.
choices.explanation: Correct. Future continuous shows planned future action.

choices.text: I have been going on a trip.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Refers to repeated past activity, not plan.

questions.text: How much do you plan to spend to finish this project?

choices.text: I will be spending $50,000 to complete it.
choices.explanation: Correct. Shows future intention for a planned action.

choices.text: I had spent $50,000 to complete it.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Refers to past perfect; not relevant.

choices.text: I have been spending $50,000 to complete it.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Ongoing, not planned future.

choices.text: I was spending $50,000 to complete it.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Refers to an interrupted past event.

choices.text: Don’t worry, he is going to be catched tomorrow.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Catched' is not a valid form; should be 'caught'.

choices.text: Don’t worry, the police can to catch him quickly.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Can' is followed by base verb, not 'to catch'.

choices.text: Don’t worry, by tomorrow he will have been caught.
choices.explanation: Correct. Future perfect passive indicates he will be caught by that time.

choices.text: Don’t worry, he is already caught today.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Doesn’t make sense with 'escaped'.

questions.text: I saw a man with a big car and house.

choices.explanation: Incorrect. Suggests past obligation, not deduction.
Correct. Logical deduction based on evidence.
Incorrect. 'Would' is used for hypothetical cases.
Incorrect. 'Can' expresses possibility, not deduction.

questions.text: What do you plan to do at 6 pm?

choices.explanation: Incorrect. Simple present doesn’t fit planned actions.

choices.text: At 6 pm, I have finished dinner.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Future perfect not suitable here.

choices.text: At 6 pm, I was eating dinner.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Past continuous is wrong tense.

choices.text: At 6 pm, I will be eating dinner.
choices.explanation: Correct. Future continuous for planned activity.

questions.text: You want to leave early to get to a concert. Why?

choices.text: The seats would have be gone when we arrived.
choices.explanation: Incorrect grammar; 'would have been gone'.

choices.text: Someone will take all the seats before we come.
choices.explanation: Incorrect tense mix.

choices.text: The seats will have been taken by the time we get there.
choices.explanation: Correct. Future perfect shows an action completed before another future event.

choices.text: There might have been too few seats for us.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Refers to past possibility, not future reason.

questions.text: Sally went home very late many days this month.

choices.text: She has been working very hard.
choices.explanation: Correct. Present perfect continuous explains repeated actions.
Also possible, but less emphasis on duration.

choices.text: She is been working very hard.
choices.explanation: Incorrect grammar; 'has been working' needed.
Incorrect; past perfect doesn’t match present timeframe.
